The section describes the structure and architecture of the Blue Planet software portfolio.

The Blue Planet portfolio provides the key software components that network operators need to streamline and digitize their service delivery lifecycle, from design, to activation and assurance. The open and modular Blue Planet product family includes dynamic inventory, service order management, multi-domain service orchestration, unified assurance and analytics, and more.
The following diagram is an overview of the Blue Planet cloud native architecture. Each part of the diagram is discussed in more detail in this section.
The common platform includes container orchestration and the Blue Planet platform. The Blue Planet platform and applications are based on a microservice architecture.

The microservices architecture comprises independent services that communicate with each other using language-agnostic REST APIs. Each microservice runs in a separate container and performs a specific task, thus facilitating a modular approach to system building. These loosely coupled services do not require changes to other services when one of them is updated. Applications are run as distributed microservices through container virtualization. These containers allow you to scale and deploy them easily across a compute cluster, as well as manage them using the standard orchestration tools.

Blue Planet can be deployed using either the BP2 platform based on Docker container orchestration or the BP K8s platform based on Kubernetes (K8s) container orchestration. Kubernetes (K8s) is an open source container orchestration system that can be used to automate the deployment and management of Blue Planet solutions. The following K8s cluster orchestration platforms are supported:
Kubernetes support varies by product. For more information on the exact deployment options, see the specific engineering guide for your product lineup.
The Blue Planet Platform is intended to support and facilitate the following:

The Blue Planet platform includes the core platform and the extended platform solution. The core platform contains the solution manager. The extended platform and the rest of the Blue Planet software are deployed as solutions that are managed by the solution manager. A solution is a set of applications that are deployed and managed together. The extended platform solution includes common services such as User Access Control (UAC), API gateway, platform health monitoring, system metrics and logging. These common services support all Blue Planet deployments.

A lineup is a set of solutions that are deployed together to provide all of the applications needed for a product or multi-product deployment. Each of the previously listed products has a corresponding lineup file.

Blue Planet’s intelligent automation solutions are combinations of products with standardized integration and consulting services. Because these solutions are built on cloud-native architectural principles, they accelerate network buildouts and enables service lifecycle automation.

You can use the Blue Planet DevOps Toolkit (DTK) to build custom applications and solutions that integrate with Blue Planet products through APIs. Use these applications to integrate Blue Planet with third party products and customer OSS and BSS systems. You can also build custom user interfaces, workflows, reports, dashboards, and portals over the Blue Planet products.

content.text: This section describes Blue Planet user and system setup tasks. The topics include:
Creating bulk users and bulk user groups
Creating and updating custom uacadmin or sysadmin role

In the App Bar UI, you can use the UAC (User Access Control) icon to create tenants and users. You can also assign roles and provide permissions to access specific resources or applications. Currently, the tenants and sub-tenants feature is not supported by BP UAA. You can also assign roles and provide permissions to access specific resources or applications.

The following default roles are provided as part of UAA to assist with establishing main user roles to access different areas of the solution. You cannot modify these default roles but you can define custom security roles. To create a custom role, see Creating a role -
When you select a row in the "Roles" window, an action bar appears at the bottom right, comprising four buttons:
All applicable actions have the button enabled. Buttons are disabled based on the following rules:
Open the "Details" window to see additional information related to the selected role(s), including a list of assigned permission.

Blue Planet uses RBAC to allow administrators to set user permissions, roles, and tenants. Each role has specific permissions attached to it, so the permissions are evaluated to determine whether an action on a resource is permitted.
User accounts can be assigned one or more user roles depending upon the amount of authorization required.
There are six user roles defined -
The set of user interfaces presented to each user is customized by the set of access roles and any access control lists that are associated with the user.
User roles are additive for the most part, but some combinations do not make sense and are not allowed. Users assigned the Customer and Read–Only roles cannot be assigned any other roles.

Administrators are required to remember to delete the active session for the user(s) on which any change of role is implemented. To delete an Active Session, follow the steps in Viewing or Terminating Active Sessions. This step will force the user session to logout and re-login. Once the user login to the UAA, the changed roles, permissions will be applied.
You can manage roles with the following procedures:

Use the following procedure to create a custom role and assign permissions and partitions as required. Before creating a role, you need to understand the minimum number of required permissions to access BPUAA. Due to the large number of permissions, you can either:

Removing a permission can impact access to BPUAA. For example, removing the view alarms permission will prevent the user from accessing alarms. When assigning a custom role to a user with security admin privilege, you must assign the additional role of sysadmin, if this user will be performing security operations such as creating a user account and creating a role.
You cannot edit default roles (role with attribute "Is Customer Modifiable: No").
You cannot delete default roles (role with attribute "Is Customer Modifiable: No").
The role is deleted from the list.
To create a custom role, see Creating a role. To view details for an existing security roles:

To delete an Active Session, follow the steps in Viewing or Terminating Active Sessions. This step will force the user session to logout and re-login. Once the user login to the UAA, the changed roles, permissions will be applied.
Blue Planet installs a single administrative user called admin within the user access control (UAC) app. The admin user sets up multiple users.
The following table describes the role privileges within Blue Planet.
Table: Role privileges within the Security app
Modify others' username, email address, or password
Create and delete API key assignments
Create, edit, and deactivate tenants or sub-tenants
*Check the Blue Planet UAA Release Notes for details on any existing issues.
**Sysadmin user must also have Application admin role to create new users and assign roles.

Admin users can create additional roles. When creating a new user account, Admin users can request that the user change their password. If this option is selected, once the account is created, the user receives an email with a link to reset their password. The user has 24 hours to activate the account before the provided link expires. When this time expires, the user can either contact an Administrator to reset the account or use the "forgot password" link on the login screen.
Before you start this procedure, make sure that you
When assigning a custom role to a user, you must assign an additional role. For security admin users, the sysadmin role is required.
The new user account displays in the User accounts page. The user then receives an email with a link to activate the account and reset the password.
The username. Maximum length allowed is 100 characters and it must be unique in a tenant. Allows username containing[a-zA-Z0-9.-_@+-].
The user’s first name. Maximum length allowed is 255 characters.
The user’s last name. Maximum length allowed is 255 characters.
The description of the user account. Maximum length allowed is 255 characters and email id must be unique.
To reset a password for a user account:
The password for the selected user account is reset.
Use this procedure to edit a user account, including setting up a forced password change request. Additional roles will be shown as created by an admin user.
Before you start this procedure, make sure that you:
Log in to BPUAA as a user with the Application admin and admin/sysadmin role. Have set up your external email service.

The email service associated with the user account is an external email service. You need a valid email address to access BPUAA; the email service associated with this email address is not part of the BPUAA solution. This external email service must be set up before you create a user account. Otherwise, the forced password change feature will not work on the user account that you are attempting to create.
This email service is an internal service that is used to send the password email to the user’s email account.
If a forced password change is not required, leave the check box unchecked.
The user account with the updated information is listed in the User accounts page. The user then receives an email with the link to reset the password.

header: Activating, deactivating, and unlocking multiple users

content.text: Blue Planet administrator users that belong to a master tenant manage multiple users. You can restrict access to users to the BPUAA application using the InActive functionality. You can also unlock users who have been locked out because of the incorrect password entries.
content.header: Activating, deactivating, and unlocking multiple users

content.text: Ensure you add a Status field to view the status of the users on the Users page.
content.header: Activating, deactivating, and unlocking multiple users

content.text: Newly created users have restricted access to the BPUAA application. These users are disabled in the system. You can activate multiple disabled users using the Active functionality on the Users page.
Activated users can be inactivated if you need to restrict the access of these users. You can inactivate multiple active users using the InActive functionality on the Users page.
The selected users are inactivated and given a status of Disabled. The inactivated users are prohibited from logging on the to the BPUAA application.
Users are locked out when an incorrect password is entered multiple times. You can unlock multiple locked out users using the Unlock functionality on the Users page.

User groups are a set of users that are assigned roles to access specific resources and applications. Using the UserGroup functionality in BPUAA, you can assign users to group. This allows you to assign similar roles to multiple users. You can also perform operations such as adding user groups, copying user groups, and editing user groups on the UserGroups page.
You can add a user group with required users and assign those users specific roles.
When you copy a usergroup, all existing users and their assigned roles are copied. You can copy an all the existing users with their assigned roles in a usergroup to a new usergroup.
The new user group appears in the UserGroups page.
You can edit a user group by modifying a user’s assigned roles or by changing other parameters of the usergroup. The only field you cannot edit is the usergroup name.
The edited usergroup appears in the list on the UserGroups page.
You can sort the fields of usergroups from the list on the UserGroups page.

content.text: A session expires if no action has been received on the browser. Actions on the browser are detected. through REST API calls. As long as API calls are made to the server, the session is kept alive. If no calls are made for the specified session inactivity timeout, the session is terminated.

content.text: The session inactivity timeout contains the maximum time a user can sit idle before the session expires and the user needs to log back in. The counter is reset each time the user does anything on the site (that is, clicks a mouse or presses a key).

The Alarm Noise Reduction use case categorizes the alarms depending on the network issues using an ML- model-driven approach. This use case classifies inflowing network alarms into important/noise(non-important) with corresponding probability (of being important) which helps the NOC to take quick action. The ML model is trained with a Binary classifier Supervised ML technique using the history of network fault alarms with necessary alarm attributes (such as severity, device type, and specific problem) and labels (presence of any comment/NOC ticket/service id) as input. The trained model is used to predict the live network alarms (important/noise) and suppress the noisy alarms using a filter.

The On-premises model training, Model evaluation, and Alarm Classification for Noise Reduction are three different use cases, which can be created and launched using the NHP container. When the user installs the NHP, by default, a sample use case for each of the above categories are created accordingly.

The user can create any of the above use cases using the respective sample use case template with custom values for parameters such as model name, data range, recall, and model to evaluate and can be launched using the NHP Swagger interface. Also, the start/stop operation can be performed using BPUAA UI Use Case Manager on the list of available use cases.

The user can use the trained model to classify the Alarms in Alarms Noise Reduction Streaming use case. By default, a sample use case is created in NHP for this use case when NHP solution is deployed and user can create more training use cases with different custom input values of recall and data range with unique model name and use case name. By starting/launching the use case, model training is performed.

The Model evaluation use case is used to evaluate the given model (specifically for current model used by the streaming use case, and also any trained models stored in the database). It comprises of Data collection and model evaluation against the new test data collected. The Model evaluation use case performs the following tasks:

By default, a sample use case is created in NHP for this use case when NHP solution is deployed and user can create more evaluation use cases with different custom input values of recall and data range with unique model name. By starting/launching the use case, model evaluation is performed.

This use case is a streaming use case which classifies inflowing network alarms into important/noise(non-important) with corresponding probability (of being important). It streams the incoming alarms from BPUAA Kafka, loads the model from Postgres, predicts and publishes the result into output Kafka.
The input to this use case can be specified in the use case json: model, threshold parameters.

The alarms streaming use case can be associated to the trained model by providing model name and corresponding threshold in the use case. By default, a sample use case will be created in NHP for this use case when the NHP solution is deployed and user can create more such use cases with respective models, but only one should be in running state. The use case has to be started to do alarm classification for noise reduction.

On-premises model training and model evaluation use cases are on-demand basis and non-repetitive unlike batch use cases. Alarms noise reduction use case is a streaming use case and also non-repetitive unlike batch use cases. The different states of a non-repeating use case are Provisioned, Running, and Error

Click house has a data size limitation on each instance before the performances starts degrading. Large customer deployments would have problems with this limitation as their cluster would poll and store huge volume of PM data. To support scale out of UAA PM DB, Data is sharded. Data Sharding partitions the data horizontally and the individual shards can be spread across multiple servers. UAA PM DB supports unlimited scale out this way without compromising on read/write performance.
Data sharding is done at table level i.e., each table can be sharded differently. But in UAA all the tables from PM/SPM/SLA/PMDA databases are sharded same. Tables from SA database are not sharded.

Shards and Replicas are configured through Clickhouse config file as Clusters. This config does not need to be specified by the user - as the UAA installation process takes care of it based on the User’s choice from one of the available Shard-Replica configuration options as mentioned below.
This list of options are for 22.02. This list may change in future releases. Acronyms: S -Shards, R - Replicas.
• 1S - 1R - Default config in a non HA deployment

In UAA, as part of self-monitoring, the system monitor’s the host VMs and UAA containers. It should be manually setup by running a script, to configure snmpV3 in VMs and importing VMs as Nodes into the system.

UAA leverages application monitoring frame work to monitor itself. Host VMs are monitored via SNMP, containers are monitored via Application monitors. In a GR setup, UAA will monitor active site applications. All uaa databases will be monitored in both active and standby site.

SeaweedFS is a simple and highly scalable distributed file system, used to manage uaa file use cases like import, application monitoring scripts, workflow scripts etc.

The upload directory /opt/ciena/bpuaa will be used to upload the files/script to seaweedFs. The periodic cron runs every 1 min and scan the folders present in /opt/ciena/bpuaa for new/modified files and upload them to seaweedfs. The files/scripts from seaweedfs will be pulled in to respective containers.
Recursive folder structure is not currently supported, all the files and scripts should be placed in respective folders.
UAA can connect to any external database, configuration should be done to connect to external db .
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs and uaa-core containers pulls the xmls from seaweedfs
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server and uaa-sbc container pulls the certificates from seaweedfs.
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server and uaa-core container pulls the import files from seaweedfs and place it in /bp2/data/imported.
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server, uaa-core and uaa-amc containers pulls the node action scripts from seaweedfs
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server, uaa-core and uaa-fme containers pulls the workflow scripts from seaweedfs.
The periodic scan uploads the scripts to seaweedfs server, uaa-core containers pulls the soap scripts from seaweedfs.
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server, uaa-core and uaa-fme containers pulls the ticketing scripts from seaweedfs.
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server, uaa-med-core container pulls the inventory from file scripts from seaweedfs.
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server, uaa-med-core container pulls the user defined crons from seaweedfs.
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server, uaa-med-pme container pulls the pm from file scripts from seaweedfs.
The periodic scan uploads the files to seaweedfs server, uaa-med-pme container pulls the user defined crons from seaweedfs.

All pm data in the topics are in CSV format. The order of columns is based on the DB table schema in click house. Respective DB schemas are below for reference.
com.ciena.bp.uaa.spm.serviceRaw : Contains generic service pm values
com.ciena.bp.uaa.spm.evcRaw : Contains raw evc pm values
UAA-Kafka-Bridge container will mimic messages from UAA internal Kafka to configured external Kafka.
UAA-Kafka-Bridge container will have a consumer created for every type of pm data collected which will be pushed to external Kafka topic respectively.
Following is the procedure to produce pm messages to the External Kafka to be done in all the hosts.
Login to the host VM and run the following commands to collect the IP of Kafka bridge container.
sudo solman sps | grep uaa-kafka-bridge | awk -F" " '{print $4}'
Create the tunnel for accessing UAA-Kafka-Bridge’s GUI for creating consumers and producers.
<local-port-to-access-ui> - This is the port through which UAA-Kafka-Bridge GUI will be accessed. It is one of the available port on the host.
<kafka-bridge-ip> - This is the ip retrieved from the Step-1.
<host-vm-ip> - IP of the host VM where UAA-Kafka-Bridge is installed.
